conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the acceleration during the interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
The graph shows velocity on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis with a straight line having a positive slope.
At time t = 1 second, the velocity is 2 m/s; at time t = 2 seconds, the velocity is 0 m/s; at time t = 3 seconds, the velocity is 2 m/s.
Velocity changes from 2 m/s to 0 m/s over the interval from 1 to 2 seconds, and from 0 m/s to 2 m/s over the interval from 2 to 3 seconds.
Acceleration is constant during these intervals as velocity changes from positive to negative and back to positive.
Acceleration is calculated as (Final velocity - Initial velocity) / Time interval = (0 - 2) / 2 = -1 m/s^2.
Negative acceleration indicates the particle is decelerating.
Particle moves in the positive direction with constant and negative acceleration.
Acceleration during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is constant and equal to -1 m/s^2.
The acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is -1 m/s^2.
